critique: This document pertains to the National Industrial Recovery Act and authorizes the Chairman of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration to designate acting replacements. Given the context of the New Deal era, this suggests government intervention in the economy. There is no information related to immigration, civil liberties, or social issues. The delegation of authority within the administration doesn't inherently expand executive power significantly, nor does it strongly favor federal or state control. The ideological tilt is moderately liberal due to the interventionist nature of the National Industrial Recovery Act.
